Description: Solid-cast fragment from left side of a headdress, probably of an Atef crown; curved horn topped by feather (only start of feather visible); fitting belonging to a relatively large figure of a god, maybe Osiris; metal well preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Since only a fragment of this crown is preserved, it is difficult to identify the god represented. It possibly belongs to a figure of Osiris since Osiris bronzes were common in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). The Osirian cult is important in the saite nome, and particularly in Sais itself as stressed by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 445), but also on a more local scale (Masson 2015). Relatively close parallel from Herakleion: Goddio and Fabre 2008, no. 202. Goddio, F. and Fabre D. 2008 (eds), Egypt’s sunken treasures, Munich. Masson, A. 2015, ‘Cult and Trade. A reflexion on Egyptian metal offerings from Naukratis’, in D. Robinson and F. Goddio (eds), Thonis Heracleion in Context, Oxford Centre for Maritime Archaeology Monograph 8, Oxford, 71-88. Masson, A. forthcoming b, ‘Naukratis: Egyptian offerings in context’, in M. Bergeron and A. Masson (eds), Naukratis in Context II: Cults, Sanctuaries and Offerings. Proceedings of the Second Naukratis Project Workshop held at the British Museum, 22nd – 23rd June 2013. Weiss, K. 2012, Ägyptische Tier- und Götterbronzen aus Unterägypten: Untersuchungen zu Typus, Ikonographie und Funktion sowie der Bedeutung innerhalb der Kulturkontakte zu Griechenland, Ägypten und Altes Testament 81.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (MB.221) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
